body:
### Contact Details (e.g. Tox ID or email)

barracuda _at_ macos-powerpc.org

### Feature Description

Qt5 is broken on some non-mainstream platforms (for example, all macOS on PowerPC and some legacy Intel), while Qt4 is perfectly functional and also much lighter dependency to build and have on the disk.
It will be great to have Qt4 supported.

I have briefly looked at the source, and it will need fixes here and there in order to build with Qt4. At the moment I am not sure though if there are some non-portable features which would be a stopper. There are quite a lot of instances of Qt5 syntax which can be more or less trivially substituted with Qt4-compatible code (say, there is a library to provide QJson* classes for Qt4). While I am nowhere an expert in Qt, I could do this part. If there are less trivial issues, I will need some help on that though.

Is anyone aware of the current status of the codebase in this regard, in principle? 

Older qmake files had remnants of Qt4 here, but it is not clear if anyone ever actually built it with Qt4. Did it work with Qt4 at some point of time, or the code was only tested with Qt5? If at least an ancient version has been known to work, it will make the task somewhat easier.

### Contribution

- [X] I would like to contribute to this feature

comment_data.body:
We're actually now on Qt6. Even supporting Qt5 and Qt6 at the same time is not entirely trivial. Have a look at https://github.com/qTox/qTox/commit/8ae3c9f0c9d3151a977554309b2203f3b464b8ca to see what it entailed to migrate from Qt5 to Qt6. All of that code will have to be `#if QT4 ... #else ... #endif`. I'm not convinced it's worth the added maintenance cost. If you have a nice way of supporting Qt4 and Qt6 at the same time, I'm open to discuss this, but I'm not very optimistic about it.

You may want to look at [tomato](https://github.com/Green-Sky/tomato) by @Green-Sky which has a lot fewer dependencies and should be significantly more portable.

Currently tomato uses SDL3, which is known not to work on powerpc, but I might be able to be convinced to refactor the code and make the SDL code plug-able and eg. be replaced with SDL2.
Assuming you can compile c++17...
We are only using the qtbase,qtsvg,qttools submodules in Qt6: https://github.com/TokTok/dockerfiles/blob/master/qtox/docker/Dockerfile.android-builder#L73 so you might be able to get that to work.

> We are only using the qtbase,qtsvg,qttools submodules in Qt6 so you might be able to get that to work.

It _might_ be possible, but at the moment we are at the stage where Qt6 with X11 backend won’t build on macOS altogether, so nothing ever been tested in that regard either.

In terms of portability the best option is arguably GTK3, but I guess there are no GTK-based clients for Tox. SDL may work (via X11), GTK4 is buggy, but has some chances. Qt5+ will require a lot of work with an unpredictable result – since there are no existing examples of something working with it on macOS ppc (for obvious reasons).
Have you tried running with the VNC platform? It's not great, but maybe just to see if we can run qTox on those systems. VNC should be pretty system-independent.

@Green-Sky Please let me know if you make a testable SDL2-based version of `tomato`. I am interested to try that.

P. S. I will see if SDL3 will build in a meanwhile, but perhaps have nothing to test it with (if it does).

labels.description: New feature for the user, not a new feature for build script
labels.name: enhancement

title: [FR]: Support Qt4
